title: Add user related workspace settings

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

labels.name: config
labels.description: VS Code configuration, set up issues

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Currently, VSCode only supports the settings.json file per workspace. This is fine if you are working on a project alone. But when working on projects as a team, different settings may be necessary for each team member, which are not necessary for the other team members. For example, one team member may need certain extensions that must be configured accordingly, but whose settings may not be necessary or may even be incorrect for the other team members because they are working on other areas of the project.

It should be possible to create a user-defined settings.json file, e.g., settings.user.json. This can then be excluded from the repository via .gitignore, while the settings.json file remains in the repository and controls the general workspace settings.

title: Github Copilot agent mode not editing python or Jupyter files
body:
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

VS Code Version:
OS Version:
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?
No (requires GitHub Copilot Chat extension to reproduce)

VS Code Version:
1.102.3

GitHub Copilot Extension Version:
1.350.0

GitHub Copilot Chat Extension Version:

0.29.1

Steps to Reproduce:
Case 1 – Jupyter notebook Python files:
Open a .ipynb file or Jupyter Python interactive cell in VS Code.

Use Copilot Agent Mode to issue a prompt like:

“Add a docstring”

“Refactor this function”

Copilot responds:

"Done! I've made the changes."

But the code is not changed.

Case 2 – Regular .py file:
Open a standard .py file in the VS Code editor.

Use Copilot Agent Mode with an edit prompt.

Copilot responds with:

"Sorry, I can't directly edit the file due to a technical limitation."

Expected Behavior:
In both .py files and Jupyter notebooks, Copilot should apply the requested code edits inline, or at minimum, show a diff or explain why editing is not possible.

Actual Behavior:
In Jupyter notebooks, Copilot falsely claims edits were made, but the code remains unchanged.

In regular Python files, Copilot refuses to edit and displays a generic error:

"Sorry, I can't directly edit the file due to a technical limitation."

Additional Notes:
Both behaviors started after updating to Copilot extension version 1.350.0.

I’m signed in with an active Copilot Chat license.

Settings enabled in settings.json:

json
Copy
Edit
"github.copilot.inlineChat.enabled": true,
"github.copilot.experimentalFeatures": true
The Chat extension is installed and enabled.

Issue is reproducible consistently across files and restarts.

title: dom - adopt more `textContent` over `innerText`
body:
Test the waters: `innerText` does more, considering styles as well. I would argue we have used `innerText` without the need for this behaviour in most cases.

See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Node/textContent#differences_from_innertext

title: FAILED to update language models

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body: Copilot Chat suddenly couldn't generate any edits in proxy mode this morning. It just kept opening files in edit mode. I tried several times but the issue persisted. So I attempted to uninstall Copilot Chat and restarted VS Code. After that, the problem shown in the logs kept occurring, along with a prompt indicating that the model wasn't activated. I've confirmed that it's not due to firewall restrictions or limitations from the company's network administrator, as the same issue occurs when I use my phone's hotspot. I've tried re-logging in, restarting VS Code, uninstalling and deleting the Copilot extension as well as the cache folder, but the problem remains. Copilot works perfectly fine in Visual Studio. I also tried network packet capture, but I couldn't identify which request is causing the problem. I'll attach the har file. [marketplace.visualstudio.com_2025_08_07_10_48_13.har.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21649901/marketplace.visualstudio.com_2025_08_07_10_48_13.har.zip) [Log] : 2025-08-07 10:22:13.652 [info] Using the Electron fetcher. 2025-08-07 10:22:13.652 [info] Initializing Git extension service. 2025-08-07 10:22:13.813 [info] Logged in as ape-byte 2025-08-07 10:22:14.243 [info] Successfully activated the vscode.git extension. 2025-08-07 10:22:14.243 [info] Enablement state of the vscode.git extension: true. 2025-08-07 10:22:14.243 [info] Successfully registered Git commit message provider. 2025-08-07 10:22:15.600 [info] Got Copilot token for ape-byte 2025-08-07 10:22:16.726 [info] copilot token chat_enabled: true, sku: copilot_for_business_seat_quota 2025-08-07 10:22:16.726 [info] GitHub.vscode-pull-request-github extension is not yet activated. 2025-08-07 10:22:16.748 [info] Registering default platform agent... 2025-08-07 10:22:16.884 [info] Fetched model metadata in 1237ms fe5c588f-b86a-41ad-9351-fb67034ceb90 2025-08-07 10:22:16.914 [info] activationBlocker from 'languageModelAccess' took for 2714ms 2025-08-07 10:22:16.916 [error] : [LanguageModelAccess] FAILED to update language models 2025-08-07 10:22:16.985 [error] : [LanguageModelAccess] FAILED to update language models vscode version : v1.99.3 github copilot chat version: 0.26.7

title: Improve file editing tool use for notebook

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

body:
- ❓  for GPT models, we use apply_patch
    * [ ] Waiting to review the failures
- ✅  for Claude models
  - use string_replace (or the new MultiEdit tool) (Claude Code used to have system instructions to nudge model to use Notebook* tools) https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/agents-and-tools/tool-use/text-editor-tool  
  - ✅ Claude Code ships Read Notebook and Edit Notebook tools
     * Based on telemetry Edit notebook tool works just fine, no need to tweak this.
     * Notebook summary updated to include line numbers for cells 
     * I.e. no need of a dedicated readnotebook tool.
  - ✅ Edit Notebook Tool uses `insert/delete/replace` with cell id
<details>
  <summary>Show Claude Tools</summary>

* Claude Read Tool (for notebooks)
  Purpose: Reads Jupyter notebook files (.ipynb) and returns all cells with their outputs, combining code, text, and visualizations.

  Required Arguments:

  - file_path (string): The absolute path to the notebook file to read

  Optional Arguments:

  - limit (number): The number of lines to read (only provide if file is too large)
  - offset (number): The line number to start reading from (only provide if file is too large)

  Key Features:

  - Processes Jupyter notebooks (.ipynb files) specially
  - Returns all cells with their outputs
  - Combines code, text, and visualizations for analysis
  - Uses cat -n format with line numbers starting at 1
  - Can handle large notebooks with limit/offset parameters
  - 

* NotebookEdit Tool

  Purpose: Completely replaces the contents of a specific cell in a Jupyter notebook (.ipynb file) with new source.

  Required Arguments:

  - notebook_path (string): The absolute path to the Jupyter notebook file to edit (must be absolute, not relative)
  - new_source (string): The new source content for the cell

  Optional Arguments:

  - cell_id (string): The ID of the cell to edit. When inserting a new cell, the new cell will be inserted after the cell with this ID, or at the beginning if not specified
  - cell_type (enum): The type of the cell - either "code" or "markdown". Defaults to current cell type if not specified. Required when using edit_mode=insert
  - edit_mode (enum): The type of edit operation:
    - "replace" (default): Replace the contents of an existing cell
    - "insert": Add a new cell at the specified position
    - "delete": Delete the cell at the specified index

  Key Features:

  - Works with Jupyter notebooks (.ipynb files) which combine code, text, and visualizations
  - Supports both code and markdown cells
  - Can replace, insert, or delete cells
  - Uses cell IDs for precise targeting
  - Designed for interactive documents commonly used in data analysis and scientific computing

  The tool is specifically designed for programmatic manipulation of Jupyter notebook cells without requiring manual editing of the JSON structure.
</details>

- ❌  for Gemini (use string_replace?) https://github.com/google-gemini/gemini-cli/blob/main/docs/tools/file-system.md
   See below notes (not going to give preference to string replace tools) 
- ✅  always have fallback for notebook edit tool, also in the error message for the builtin tools
- ❌  Create more stests and run against the test data
    Given Notebook Edit tool has > 98.5% success rate, i don't think we'd learn anything new here.

# NOTE
* No need to explicitly ask model to use string_replace or apply_patch, as Model can decide.
* Also notebook edit tool will not perform any speculative decoding, hence in theory notebook edit and string replace/apply patch are equally performant. 
* Notebook has a higher success rate > 98.5%
* :runner: We do however tell model to use Notebook Edit took, given the fact that this has > 98.5% success rate, we might end up deciding to leave this as is, as Notebook Edit is significantly better.

title: feat(scm): Customizable SCM Graph History Item Formatting (GitLens-style Variable Support)
body:
### Overview

This PR implements customizable formatting for SCM Graph History items in VS Code #255719, allowing users to personalize how commit history is displayed in the Source Control Graph view. Inspired by GitLens, it introduces a configuration option for variable-based formatting, enabling greater flexibility and clarity for teams and individuals.

### Key Changes

#### 1. Configuration Setting

Added `"scm.graph.historyItemFormat"` to `src/vs/workbench/contrib/scm/browser/scm.contribution.ts`:

- **Type:** `string`
- **Description:** Controls the format of each history item in the Source Control Graph view. Supports variables:
  - `${author}` — Commit author name
  - `${authorEmail}` — Author email
  - `${subject}` — Commit subject/title
  - `${message}` — Full commit message
  - `${hash}` — Full commit hash
  - `${displayId}` — Shortened commit hash
  - `${date}` — Relative date (e.g., "2 hours ago")
  - `${timestamp}` — Full timestamp

**Examples:**
- `${subject}`
- `${displayId} - ${subject}`
- `${author} • ${subject}`
- `[${displayId}] ${subject} by ${author}`
- `${subject} (${date})`

#### 2. Formatting Function

Introduced `formatHistoryItem` in `src/vs/workbench/contrib/scm/browser/util.ts`:

- Replaces variables in the format string with actual commit data.
- Handles missing values gracefully (empty string fallback).
- Preserves line breaks in commit messages.
- Removes trailing spaces for clean appearance.

#### 3. Renderer Integration

Updated `HistoryItemRenderer` in `src/vs/workbench/contrib/scm/browser/scmHistoryViewPane.ts`:

- Observes configuration changes for `"scm.graph.historyItemFormat"` using VS Code's observable pattern.
- Uses `autorun` for real-time UI updates when settings change.
- Applies custom formatting via `formatHistoryItem`.

#### 4. Comprehensive Testing

Added test coverage in `src/vs/workbench/contrib/scm/test/browser/util.test.ts`:

- Tests all supported variables.
- Validates default and multi-variable formats.
- Checks handling of missing values and edge cases.
- Includes GitLens-style example formats.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.102.3 (system setup)
- OS Version:  Microsoft Windows 11 家庭中文版 10.0.26100

<!-- Failed to upload "屏幕录制 2025-08-07 092720.mp4" -->

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code.
2. Open the llama-factory project.
3. Press Shift+Ctrl+P to open the Command Palette, then select "Python: Select Interpreter".
4. Choose an existing Python virtual environment (e.g., llm).
5. In the VS Code PowerShell terminal, run the command to start llama-factory.
6. Observed Behavior: The terminal fails to find the startup file.
7. Manually running conda activate llm in the same terminal shows:
8. Error: conda is not activated.
9. However, launching a Conda-enabled PowerShell terminal externally (outside VS Code) allows successful activation of the virtual environment and running llama-factory.

Possible Workarounds (if any):
Manually sourcing Conda in VS Code’s settings.json (e.g., "terminal.integrated.shellArgs.windows": ["-ExecutionPolicy", "Bypass", "-NoExit", "-Command", "& 'C:\\path\\to\\conda\\Scripts\\activate.ps1'"]).
Using the external Conda terminal and opening VS Code from there

title: Feature Request: Toggle Command for Showing Coverage in Explorer View

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: verification-needed
labels.description: Verification of issue is requested

labels.name: testing
labels.description: Built-in testing support

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
**Background**
Our extension surfaces test coverage information via the Explorer View using the built-in VS Code coverage UI. This is enabled through the `testing.showCoverageInExplorer` setting.

While this setting works well, it’s currently only accessible via the Settings UI or by manually editing settings.json. We’ve explained this to our users, but feedback is for a toggle option to turn the coverage view on and off as needed, and the lack of a quick toggle makes this workflow inconvenient.

**Problem**
For many developers, always showing coverage in the Explorer View adds visual noise or isn’t needed all the time. So they disable it, but once disabled, they may never re-enable it, simply because going into settings is too much friction. This means users miss out on a feature because it's "set and forget" and there's no lightweight / fluid way to turn it back on when they need it.

---

While we could extend our extension with an extra option / setting to control this behavior (e.g. where the `testing.showCoverageInExplorer` is ALWAYS enabled, but we only emit the coverage information on an as needed basis via our own mechanism), we feel such a mechanism would be useful as part of VS Code's first class Testing functionality.

body: - Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.30.2025080503 - VS Code Version: 1.103.0-insider (Universal) - OS Version: Darwin arm64 24.6.0 - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Claude Sonnet 4 - Logs: Steps to Reproduce: 1. Add a folder to your `.gitignore`. 2. Ask GitHub Copilot to search for or update files in this ignored folder. ### Expected GitHub Copilot returns searched results from these files. ### Actual GitHub Copilot is returned no information for any files that are excluded from the workspace or in a `.gitignore`. ## Details I have a folder `.copilot-tracking` that is in our `.gitignore`, because it's a dumping ground for intermediate files for GitHub Copilot to use and reference. However, because this folder is git ignored, the `file_search` and `grep_search` tools exclude anything in this folder from being searched... A possible feature request, would it make more sense to have a setting for this? Such as one where I can list out **which folders** to **exclude** from `file_search`, `grep_search`, `semantic_search`, etc... Instead of only relying on workspace excluded files/folders and .gitignore? As another example, my codebase has a docs folder that I WANT to be **excluded** from `semantic_search`. Which, right now, I'm unable to do this because I would need to add to the .gitignore or exclude it from the workspace... Feel free to reach out to me for more details.

Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
MCP-UI is [gaining](https://shopify.engineering/mcp-ui-breaking-the-text-wall) adoption. We have proposed API for [extension-contributed tool rendering](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/257761), and we should consider including a built-in extension that would render MCP UI like we do for notebook rendering scenarios.

- Spec https://mcpui.dev/guide/embeddable-ui
- Repo https://github.com/idosal/mcp-ui

I still need to dive more into the spec to see feasibilty/challenges of this in our application.

cc @digitarald @mjbvz

title: Add support for a help link when MCP assisted installation fails
body: This is in support of https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/257679. This will also support https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259901 if, for example, we move to using `npm` for the "does the package exist" check and npm is not available. I am working in using the server.json contained in NuGet packages to improve MCP installation. To do these, I need to invoke `dotnet tool install` commands to download the package. If the user does not have `dotnet` installed, we should let them known. This is prior to the MCP server being installed so the existing notification flow will not kick in yet. The URL and label are optionally sent back as part of the error. I believe this is a useful additional to the contract of `github.copilot.chat.mcp.setup.validatePackage`. It looks like this: Also, added `dotnet` to the list of recognized missing commands in case `dotnet tool exec` is used. Also, fix a misnamed editor service dependency.

title: WSL Terminal Launch Command Broken in Windows 10
body:
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.102.3 (user setup) - OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19045 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Use a Windows 10 environment 2. Run "Create New Terminal (With Profile)" 3. Select a WSL profile 4. Observe that bash.exe has been selected as the wslPath command instead of wsl.exe 5. Attempt to launch a WSL profile and observe that it fails 6. Compare the incorrect (bash.exe) and correct (wsl.exe) commands

Prior to PR #248438, bash.exe was used for Windows < 16299, and wsl.exe was used for Windows >= 16299. (WSL docs related to 16299: ["bash.exe has been replaced with wsl.exe"](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wsl/troubleshooting#:~:text=bash.exe%20has%20been%20replaced%20with%20wsl.exe)) The PR changed the behavior to compare with 22000 (Windows 11) instead, so VS Code on Windows 10 now tries (and fails) to use bash.exe instead of wsl.exe. The PR reportedly didn't fix the issue (#233618) that it was trying to ([#233618 comment](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/233618#issuecomment-2954070195)), so maybe it can simply be reverted? I had trouble searching for duplicate issues, so my apologies if one has already been created. Other people have experienced this issue: https://www.reddit.com/r/bashonubuntuonwindows/comments/1lao2c3/suddenly_vscode_terminal_trying_to_execute/ https://jamesephelps.com/2025/06/27/wsl-terminals-wont-start-in-vscode-version-1-101-cwindowssystem32bash-exe-d-debian-terminated-with-exit-code-2/ https://kodekloud.com/community/t/facing-error-realted-to-wsl2-in-the-vscode-when-opening-terminal-in-vscode/480384 Thank you.

title: Grade not calculating correctly Assignment 6-1

labels.name: *caused-by-extension
labels.description: Issue identified to be caused by an extension

body:
Hi, I think my grade calculation is not correct. I have entered the correct code and when I run my code it matches the instructions perfectly. When I "calculate my grade", the calculation is 57.14%. I received the exact grade of 57.14% when I had the code incorrect as well. It's like it is stuck and can not calculate correctly. The code is below. 
Thank you for your help, Cole Gordon

import math

def newton(x):
    """Use Newton's method to approximate the square root of x."""
    tolerance = 0.000001
    estimate = 1.0

    while True:
        estimate = (estimate + x / estimate) / 2
        difference = abs(x - estimate ** 2)
        if difference <= tolerance:
            break

    return estimate

def main():
    while True:
        user_input = input("Enter a positive number or enter/return to quit: ")
        if user_input == "":
            break

        x = float(user_input)
        program_estimate = newton(x)
        python_estimate = math.sqrt(x)

        print("The program's estimate is", program_estimate)
        print("Python's estimate is", python_estimate)

main()

title: Feature Request: Show file modification time in Explorer

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Dear VS Code Team,

Thank you for developing Code-OSS!
`Code - OSS Version: 1.102.0`
In the Explorer, it will be helpful if there is modification time displayed as a column on the right-side of files.
There are currently no extensions in the marketplace that achieve this functionality.
It will be very helpful to see modification times of not only source files, but also output files, which are frequently generated in data science workflows.

Many thanks for considering this feature request!

title: Copilot Chat: chat summarization makes broken and bad edits

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

body: - Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.30.2025080503 - VS Code Version: 1.103.0-insider (Universal) - OS Version: Darwin arm64 24.6.0 - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Claude Sonnet 4 - Logs: - Ping me directly for my captured `.copilotmd` files - pre-summarization - `ourRequestId`: `511be9e9-56b9-4e69-90b0-2ea268894107` - post-summarization - `ourRequestId`: `f2a22579-4e4e-43e0-ac27-1b5b3ed6efe8` Steps to Reproduce: 1. Work on a long running conversation with Github Copilot Chat in Agent mode. 2. Have Agent mode "Summarize conversation history" in the middle of you asking it to make a change somewhere. 3. Have Agent mode make the change. ### Expected: Agent mode should make the correct change in the correct locations in the file with all relevant information in its context. Agent mode should do the following immediately after summarization: 1. Attach files that are being edited to the context of the conversation, WITHOUT truncation. - If they're too large then copilot should instruct the model to read the file(s) back in. 2. Copilot should have the model rebuild some of its context before making ANY edits... ### Actual: Agent mode attempted to `replace_string_in_file` with an `"oldString"` that does not exist in the file, to a `"newString"` with content that it made up based on its current context (that does not include all of the most relevant data). Agent mode **did not** do any of the following: 1. Continue to send the files that are being edited as NON-TRUNCATED `attachments`. 2. The model did not request to `read_file` the file being modified back into its context before making edits. ## Details I have a custom chatmode that reviews documents and files, and then updates a research markdown document with details. I told it to research how to support something, the following happened: - It went and read in corresponding files and searched for text. - Agent mode then kicked in to "Summarizing conversation history". - The model then attempted to immediately edit the document based on its summarized conversation history. - Looking through the edit log it's missing the following: - Any attachment or content for the file being edited. - The `outputs.tf` that was read in previously before the summarization. - It does include the tool response from the `grep_search` that was done immediately before summarization The response then failed and the tool instructed copilot to replace based on the attached file. - The model responded with a wonky `corrected_target_snippet`. - This would have been wrong anyways, because it's currently trying to make an incorrect bad edit to my file. - This still failed as it looks like it just used the same text from `Problematic target snippet:` that was provided to the model. This is likely because of the prompt for the tool for the heal string replace, telling the model to use PERFECT literal matches (when it does not have any other context for what it's replacing) Since replacement still failed, the model was told to update its search string, this resulted in the model reading in parts of the research document. - The model found sections of the document that were close to the replacement that it is trying to make. - It then made these edits, incorrectly, with bad data, all throughout the document. Ping me directly and I can share my captured `.copilotmd` files

title: Filter shell commands from Python REPL LSP completions
body:
The LSP completion provider for Python REPL was showing shell commands like `npm`, `addgnurhome`, and `kernelophys-support` alongside legitimate Python completions. This created a confusing experience where terminal commands appeared as Python suggestions.

**Before:**
![Shell commands appearing in Python completions](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/85539d35-02f1-42e1-bf99-683a03f5ec4a)

**Root Cause:**
The `LspCompletionProviderAddon` was only filtering out `wordbasedCompletions` but allowed all other completion items from the LSP provider to pass through, including shell commands that somehow made it into the completion results.

**Solution:**
Added `isShellCommand()` filtering function that identifies and excludes:
- Common shell commands (`npm`, `git`, `curl`, `docker`, etc.)
- Package managers (`yarn`, `pip`, `pnpm`, `conda`, etc.)
- System tools (`ls`, `cp`, `sudo`, `systemctl`, etc.)
- Build tools (`make`, `cmake`, `gradle`, etc.)
- Issue-specific commands (`addgnurhome`, `kernelophys-support`, etc.)

The filter uses smart heuristics:
- Preserves Python-appropriate completion kinds (`Module`, `Class`, `Method`, `Function`, `Keyword`)
- Filters `Text` and `Variable` kinds with shell command characteristics
- Handles edge cases like Python modules with dashes (e.g., `pip-tools`)

**Testing:**
Added comprehensive test coverage that verifies shell commands are filtered while Python completions are preserved. All filtering logic validated with standalone tests.

Fixes #258835.

title: Issue Reporter -- Add Create/Preview option + repo routing choices

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: issue-reporter
labels.description: Issue reporter widget issues

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body:
Looking into enhancements for the native issue reporter within vscode. There have been changes within the last ~6mo that changed the default behavior from "Preview" to "Create", leading to more issues created at a lower quality bar. While the classifier bot can take care of a portion of this load, there is still feedback that asks explicitly for "Preview" as the default behavior for ease of adding screenshots etc.

- [x] Add dropdown option for issue reporter to allow users to choose create vs preview. (default: preview) https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/257529
  - https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/257593 
- [x] Add optional routing UX if specific users need to file an issue against a private repository
  - https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/263703
- [x] Support workbench setting for preferred browser
  - https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/260950

--- 
Notes:
- Look into closed issues labeled verified from prior couple milestones, identifying whether or not them come from issue reporter or gh website. Should be identifiable based on body content at the end, and markdown comments from the template.
  - Should give an indication for where the more "useful" issues come from
  - Maybe look at closed issues as not planned and/or `spam` to maybe see where users are sending those from
- Reach out to raymond and harald about potential issues re: org id's and repo destinations
